title: Stocks Slide After U.S. Expands Export Blacklist
text:
By Caitlin Ostroff

-- U.S. stocks fall

-- Europe slides after rally in Asia

-- Oil prices fall

U.S. stocks fell after Washington expanded its list of blacklisted Chinese firms, a move expected to complicate this week's trade talks with Beijing.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 309 points, or 1.2%, in mid-morning trading. The S&P 500 slid 1.3% and Nasdaq Composite lost 1.4%.

The declines came a day after the Commerce Department added 28 Chinese entities to an export blacklist, citing their role in Beijing's repression of Muslim minorities in northwest China. The U.S. said the move wasn't related to trade negotiations with Beijing.

Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang urged the U.S. to withdraw its move against the Chinese firms, and said, "China will continue to take firm and strong measures to uphold its national sovereignty, our security and development interests."

High-level trade trade talks are set to resume Thursday, with a delegation led by China's top trade envoy, Liu He, scheduled to meet with U.S. officials in Washington.

The Trump administration has rattled markets in recent months with conflicting signals on trade, sometimes threatening to escalate the fight with Beijing while periodically offering signs that a resolution to the dispute is getting closer.

China's recent large purchases from the U.S. soybean market had signaled a potential thaw in relations. But China has also sought to narrow the scope of the trade negotiations, putting aside national-security issues and adding to market concerns that an immediate resolution is unlikely.

"They will not reach an agreement at any price," said Ipek Ozkardeskaya, a senior analyst at London Capital Group. "Despite the optimism we see, there's a chance this week ends with another disappointment."

Shares in Domino's Pizza Inc. erased early declines to trade up 0.3% after the chain pizza restaurant said that sales growth may be slower than previously expected.

Elsewhere, the Stoxx Europe 600 and German DAX were both down 1%.

Shares in London Stock Exchange Group fell 4.6% after Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing pulled a $36.6 billion bid for its London rival, a deal that would have united two major trading hubs.

German industrial output grew slightly in August, according to official data. The rise was a surprise after a dismal reading on Monday of manufacturing orders for the same month.

Industrial output increased 0.3% in August over July in adjusted terms, the statistical office said. Despite the better-than-expected output, the industry remains in a downturn, the Ministry of Economics said.

The British pound also stumbled on political headwinds Tuesday, falling 0.6% against the euro and the U.S. dollar amid increased skepticism a Brexit deal could be reached at the European Union Council of State next week.

The yield on the 10-year German bund edged down to minus 0.594%, according to Tradeweb, from minus 0.572% Monday afternoon. The yield on 10-year Treasurys also slipped to 1.516%, from 1.552% on Monday. Bond yields fall as prices rise.

U.S. crude oil futures fell 1.2% to $52.11 a barrel, and gold gained 0.5%.

The Japanese yen and the Swiss franc, both viewed as havens, gained 0.3% against the dollar.

In Asia, Japan's Nikkei climbed 1% and Korea's Kospi gained 1.2%. Stocks in Shanghai and Hong Kong rose 0.3% as Chinese markets returned from a holiday.

Alexander Osipovich and Eva Dou contributed to this article.
